clouds.title: Cloud Types
clouds.description: Identification of clouds according to their altitude (level) and shape. The images are representative examples.

descriptions.cirrus: High, thin, and wispy clouds composed of ice crystals. They often indicate fair weather.
descriptions.cirrocumulus: Thin, white layers with a wavy or pebbly appearance. Known as a 'mackerel sky'.
descriptions.cirrostratus: A transparent, whitish cloud veil that often produces halos around the Sun or Moon.
descriptions.altocumulus: Mid-level clouds that appear as white or grayish patches or layers. Generally associated with settled weather.
descriptions.altostratus: A grayish or bluish cloud layer that totally or partly covers the sky. The Sun or Moon may be visible as if through ground glass.
descriptions.nimbostratus: A thick, dark gray cloud layer associated with continuous rain or snow. They cover the entire sky and blot out the Sun.
descriptions.stratus: A gray, low, and uniform cloud layer, similar to fog but not touching the ground. It can produce light drizzle.
descriptions.stratocumulus: Low, lumpy clouds in layers or patches with blue sky visible between them. They rarely produce precipitation.
descriptions.cumulus: Detached, puffy, flat-based clouds. They are the 'fair-weather' clouds but can grow into cumulonimbus.
descriptions.cumulonimbus: Imposing, dense clouds with significant vertical development. They are associated with thunderstorms, heavy rain, hail, and tornadoes.
